segments.text: This is an interview with Mary Garrison by Rose George on April 14, 1990 at Mrs. Garrison's home concerning her nursing in Vietnam.
And in the interest of accumulating knowledge, I'm asking you to donate this tape to me or to the Texas A&M Oral History Collection in the University Archives.
Is that all right with you?
That is fine.
OK.
So when and where were you born?
I was born September 17, 1945, in Christian County, Illinois.
And where did you get your education?
I went to local schools, a parochial school in Morrisonville, Illinois.
It's a small Catholic school.
And then a high school at Morrisonville Community High School.
And then college, I graduated from St. Louis University in St. Louis.
And then where did you go to nursing school?
That was St. Louis University School of Nursing and Health Sciences.
Why did you decide to go into the Army?
At the time, there was a student nurse program.
You could join at the beginning of either your junior or senior year and have an obligation of two or three years.
The Army picked up the tab, the total tab, for tuition, fees, room and board.
We were paid first as...
PFCs in the WAC, Women's Army Corps.
And then six months before we graduated, we were commissioned second lieutenants, and our pay went up accordingly.
During senior year, I was getting $348 a month, plus school was paid for, and I owed two years.
I had done it during my senior year.
And did you intend to go to Vietnam?
Vietnam was the farthest thing from my mind.
Even when I got to basic training at Fort San Houston, that was in November of 67.
We were told then, and something should have told us,
I mean, this should have told us that something was going on.
It was a very, very large class, probably 300 in the class.
But we were told that no one, no nurses were in Vietnam except those who had volunteered to go.
They were actively recruiting the male nurses at that time.
And there were between 40 and 50 of them in that class.
And they were asking for volunteers.
By May, most of the people that I knew from that basic class already had orders to go.
So things changed very quickly.
What did you consider to be your main reason for being in Vietnam?
Well, to help care for the wounded.
The motto
The theme of the Medical Service Corps is to conserve the fighting strength.
And I took that to mean saving lives, taking care of the wounded.
And how much nursing experience did you have before you went to Vietnam?
Not that much.
I went on active duty in the Army in September of 67.
And of course we didn't get to our first duty station until early November.
And I was in Vietnam the next September, September of 68, so less than a year of active duty work.
After I graduated in the summer, from June until September, we could not go on to active duty until we had passed our state boards.
I had taken those in June, but we didn't get results until early September.
How did they prepare you before you went?
Well, we had a five-week basic course at Port Sam.
We learned
military protocol you know the marching saluting how to wear the uniforms and there are several uniforms they had several ways of making sure that we knew how to wear the uniform
The blue, the army dress blues are a little different.
The insignia is just a little bit different.
And so that inspection was a cocktail party where we all had to appear and be presented to the general and so on.
We had classes on the military paperwork.
It's different in military hospitals.
than it is from civilian hospitals.
They have their own forms and nursing notes are much abbreviated in some cases, in many cases.
And so we had to learn how to use the paperwork.
We went out probably every day for a week to Camp Bullis.
and wore our fatigues and ate from our mess kits and attended classes on weapons familiarization.
We did not, the women nurses did not shoot guns.
We sat and watched these demonstrations, but we did not actually fire weapons.
The men did.
The men bivouacked overnight, a couple of nights.
We were always treated like, this is fun, hey.
At the end of the day, when they bussed us back into town, and it was a good 25 or 30 miles back into town, they dropped us off first at the pit
which was the medical field service school's officers club, and a real rocking place.
I mean, it was fun.
It was a lot of fun.
And they wanted us back there.
One day, they brought the Fort Sam Houston band out to Camp Bullis, and the band played for us during lunch.
One day, we had...
field rations, sea rations, for lunch.
What were some other things we did?
We went into laboratories and practiced starting IVs, practiced doing tracheotomies.
It seems like there was another procedure we practiced.
on goats.
They had anesthetized the goats and there'd be three or four of us at each station with each goat practicing these things.
We had lectures on, one lecture was on triage, how the casualties would be divided
you know, what decided or how it was decided who went into surgery first.
They had a mock-up Vietnamese village, which was, you know, just laughable.
It was nothing like the villages really were.
And what was your unit assignment and where were you assigned?
I went to the 24th of Ag Hospital on Long Bend Post.
That was about 16 miles, I think southeast, sort of southeast of Saigon.
They were separated by a big interstate highway.
It was just a real quick trip by car into Saigon, or a quick by chopper, too.
There were two... Long Bend Post was a huge post, probably the size of Fort Sam Houston.
Just really big, and it was just nothing but Army.
It was an area that had been scraped clean.
And then Army built... Army...
buildings put up and a big perimeter around it.
And it served as a, I think it really grew up, I heard once, really grew up after Tet.
They got a lot of the headquarters or whatever out of Saigon and onto this place where they could really secure them.
They had a big population of generals.
They had acres and acres of, you know,
buildings or house trailers where senior officers lived.
There was a big jail there, I mean a huge jail.
Anyone in country that had to be put up a while was brought down to the LBJ.
There was another evac hospital.
It was on the perimeter, and when I was given a choice, you know, where I wanted to go, and that surprised me.
I had no idea I'd get to choose where I wanted to go.
It was explained that the 93rd was on the perimeter, and occasionally took small arms fire, and the 24th was more of a center of the post.
I said, I want that one.
And I was tired also of...
You know, it had been a 23 hour trip over there.
And I was very, very tired and I was a little bit leery about traveling up country too.
I didn't think it was safe to go in a jeep anywhere and I didn't think it was safe to go in a chopper anywhere.
So I was real glad to just stay right there.
And what were the living conditions like?
Very good.
You know, very simple, but much better than I expected.
We had four long wooden buildings.
There was a fifth one.
That was the one in the middle.
That one housed the Officers Club.
But then there were two on either side that housed 10 to 12 rooms.
And these were private rooms.
The buildings were designed to, you know, not be air-conditioned.
They were screened and the walls were wooden slats out like louvers.
More than halfway up and then big screened-in windows and then we're known.
no ceilings.
Well, people had improved on those quite a bit over time, and right away, somebody insisted on building in my wall.
I already had a ceiling, and we shared a bathroom on the latrine, about three sinks and three stalls.
couple of showers, but they were all inside that, you know, that building.
Concrete floors.
You know, we brought things in and it really made them pretty comfortable.
I had a bed with an innerspring mattress.
Certainly not an army cot.
Not a swayback army cot.
And how did you react to the injuries that you saw when you first got there?
The injuries?
I think I was just sort of numbed by the whole trip over and just, you know, accepted what I saw.
These things stuck in my mind and I never forgot them or eventually, you know, I started remembering them again.
But
I don't remember ever turning away, you know, being repulsed, not being able to look at them or not being able to do for them.
I mentioned triage.
One of the stages of triage is a stage called expectant.
And that's the stage that you just don't try to do anything for.
You can tell that these people are still alive but they are terribly wounded.
Their wounds are going to require hours and hours and hours of surgery and then maybe you still won't get a good result.
The hospital I was assigned to was
the neurosurgery and maxillofacial surgery center for all of the South, the South part of South Vietnam, for three and four core.
And we had a 50 bed neurosurgery ward.
Well, it was 45 to 50 beds.
And, well, I don't know how many beds for the maxillofacial.
certainly it was no more than one ward.
But the patients of ours that were labeled expectant were the head injured.
They were out of it and they knew nothing.
There's a certain way of stimulating them that gives you a certain reflex that tells you that the brain is gone.
We did not have EEG machines.
You know, it was the equivalent of, you know, these were flatline head injuries.
And yet they lived for a while.
They could live for days.
And the thing I do remember is the very first day I worked, and that was probably five or six days after I had gone to that hospital, or a good week after I'd come in country.
That first day, there were two American GIs that came in as expectants, and they were put at the back of the ward and just left there.
And then, you know, the things I had heard at Fort Sam made sense.
Back then, to me, it was something to learn for a test.
I mean, it really had no... Well, I suppose at that time, I never thought I'd be in Vietnam, for one thing.
And then it really did hit home that this is real.
I was assigned to the pre-op and recovery ward.

The back end of the ward was pre-op, where we held patients, kept them stabilized, watched them, gave them additional pain medicine if need be, hung extra blood and IV fluids, reinforced their bandages, talked to them.
Just held them there until it was their turn to go into surgery, which was next door to us.
And then the front half of the ward was set up as a recovery ward.
And it had everything around each bed that you'd find here, or that you would have found 20 years ago.
And they came out of surgery wrapped up, bandaged in clean bandages, white bandages.
And they looked like what you would find back home after an accident.
But the fellows as they went in were still on the litters that they had been picked up on.
Their clothes had been cut away, but they were still lying in what remained of their clothes.
Some of their bandages were the green field dressing bandages.
They had dirt, crud, you know, they had the whole thing still attached to them.
They never did get really cleaned off.
Somebody who has done primarily OR or operating room nursing would just really be appalled at what we sent into the operating room.
I mean, we sent them in very dirty.
And there were some places that did attempt to clean them
off better before they sent them into, even into the hospital.
The third field hospital in Saigon had a set of showers set up, shower heads set up at the edge of their helipad.
And before they even took them into the hospital, they hosed them down.
You can imagine, you know, just being, you know, those guys were already shocky from their wounds.
And then to get a blast of probably cold water.
I don't know, I've forgotten the question.
The injuries.
The expectant head patients, I said, were kept put in a corner in the back.
I don't remember ever seeing them up.
another time when we had two Americans there together.
It was not unusual to have two patients back there.
You know, we received Vietnamese patients, civilians, the Arvins.
We had VC Viet Cong and we had NVA, the North Vietnamese Army.
We also had
Cambodians at times.
We had Koreans.
We called them ROKs, Republic of Korean Soldiers.
There was a Korean soldier who came in once.
He was not really expected.
He could have lived a while.
He had a very high spinal cord injury.
Spinal cord injuries, whatever part of the spinal cord, they qualified as surgery patients and they would come to our hospital too.
He'd had a very high one and the cord was severed so high that he wasn't able to breathe on his own.
And he was brought in, and somebody was bagging him, you know, mashing the ambu bag, breathing for him.
He had a trach put in, and two or three surgeons got into a fuss over him.
We had a unit attached to our hospital called the RARE unit, the Walter Reed Army Institute of Research.
And I think all of the major medical centers had a research team of some sort.
Well, Rare was over there.
attached to our hospital and doing trauma studies.
And so anyone who had really gross trauma, they did studies on.
They did blood tests.
I don't know what else they did.
I was aware of the blood tests.
What I was most aware of was that they did blood gas studies on them.
Actually, they went into the artery and got samples of blood and had the equipment to analyze it.
This is not... Well, I don't know how sophisticated the equipment...
The test is, but it's very necessary equipment when you're dealing with chest wounds.
You need it for people who've had, may need it for people who've had heart attacks.
There are a lot of things that are not terribly abnormal or out of the ordinary that you could use this test for, but it was not standard equipment even for an evacuation hospital.
And in the back hospital, it was a pretty well-equipped hospital.
Well, anyway, the rare team was there, and the doctor in charge wanted that patient for his test.
He was not well-liked.
He was kind of an obnoxious type, and he didn't want to take care of him afterwards.
Most often, the patients, they'd
They did the studies on the expectants and on others, but they did not assume responsibility for the patients afterwards.
This fellow was going to need a respirator.
He was going to have to be on the
striker frame.
It's a skinny little bed with sort of a sandwich.
You can turn the patient from front to back.
And you don't misalign his spinal cord by turning him that way.
And you can turn him easily.
And one doctor was screaming he was going to be tying up a respirator.
Another one was screaming that
Even if he lived and got out of our hospital without a major infection, he would get one soon as he got medevaced back to Korea.
And the Koreans didn't have the rehab.
This is what this was, was a rehab patient.
Didn't have the rehab facilities to take care of him.
And so the three, in their fussing and their fighting,
I don't know that a neurosurgeon was ever there.
I can't remember who the third fellow was.
It may have been a neurosurgeon, but I just can't remember.
The second was a general surgeon that was very, very good.
He was just an extremely good surgeon.
And I thought a lot of him.

ended up the three of us felt most fellows um two of them decided they would put him down rather than take care of him and rather than let the rare team have him and then notice him the responsibility for him afterwards and it was all over very very quickly it was this big scene that you know the three of them were around yelling and the nursing staff was
You know, started standing around, what is going on here?
What's going to happen?
And before you knew it, they had given this man a bolus of, I don't know what it was, morphine, Demo, and stopped bagging him.
And he just, you know, he just went out and was dead very soon.
This man had been trying to talk.
Of course, he couldn't talk with the trach in his throat unless it recovered, and then he couldn't be back.
But he was trying to talk.
There was another Korean there who was watching this, who was telling him what was going on or, you know, asking questions of him.
I thought about him a lot, not so much then.
But in these later years, it was very unusual for him to have received medical care as quickly as he did.
Someone very quickly put a trach in his throat and established an airway.
Either had a bag or actually blew into his chest.
He was trying to communicate.
He was awake.
You know, the man would have lived a while.
He had things to say.
And yet he was just put down.
An American soldier would have been operated on, would have been given the chance.
He may or may not have gotten home, but he would have been operated on.
Another time, we were having a push of some sort.
We call the mass cow situations, masses of casualties.
We had a lot going on, a lot of patients in there, a lot of doctors coming and going on the way into surgery and so on.
And this doctor came in pushing a patient
And the doctor was frantic.
This fellow had a tracheostomy and it was bleeding.
It was bleeding from around it and bleeding a lot.
And he was in distress.
He wasn't getting enough air.
And the doctor grabbed me.
And I hadn't been there very long.
And he said, I've got to revise this, this trach.
And, you know, I just, I stayed there with him.
He was very rattled.
He was very scared himself.
And I didn't realize until later he had not been in country very long himself.
The fact that he was a doctor didn't make him any less immune to being shaken up by what he was, you know, involved in.
But the time, it shook me that he was so shaken.
But I just stayed right by him.
I stayed at the patient's head right across the gurney from the doctor.
And every time he asked for something, I grabbed somebody going by or caught somebody's eye and said, get me this, get me that.
I didn't know what he was doing.
I certainly couldn't advise him.
But I calmed him down.
I talked him through it.
And
You know, he did revise the thing, got it in so the fellow was breathing, and then they went off into surgery.
And I have no idea what happened after that.
One time, one of the orthopedic surgeons started working on a fellow.
He just had a wound in his foot, and it was one of these self-inflicted wounds.
And the surgeon was real mad about that.
He was just being very judgmental and screaming and hollering.
And carrying on, he asked for a tracer.
He said, I think I can debride this a little bit here.
I won't have to go into the, you know, open up an operating room just for this toe.
And it was just the middle toe.
And he started working on it, working on it.
And the kid was screaming, giving more.
when Lyda came, pretty soon he had amputated that toe.
He thought he was just going to clean it up and tear away the dead skin.
And so he ended up amputating that toe right there with just local anesthetic.
We had doctors who couldn't let go of their patients.
They had a pretty good success rate.
I don't remember the exact statistics anymore.
But it was like 95% of the men who were picked up alive off the battlefield and brought to a hospital lived.
Now, of course, there were degrees of living.
But it was amazing how many people did live with really horrendous wounds.
But they, you know, they didn't like, they didn't like losing.
And I remember a patient who just went, he threw a fatty embolus, a fat clot.
It's a little worse than, it's worse than a blood clot.
People can recover, but it's a major problem when they do this.
And this fellow did not recover.
He had a respiratory arrest.
We went through all that.
I don't remember him ever being really awake after that.
And he was on a respirator.
And he kept going downhill to the point of...
He couldn't suction him.
He had a tracheostomy that was attached to the respirator.
If you take him off the respirator long enough to suction him, he'd stop.
I mean, he was getting no blood at all and no circulation.
And yet the doctor would scream at you to suction him.
I remember, you know, it was very obvious to me and everyone around us that this guy was gone.
He was just gone and had been on the respirator, you know, long past the time he should have been on it.
He just barely disconnected and his eyes were dilate and he was waxy looking.
And I remember having to tell the doctor, just, you know, let it go.
He's gone.
You've got to take it home.
I guess after so much time expended on a patient, you know, they can't save themselves.
This is it for some care.
There was a patient...
He was on a striker frame because he had so many wounds, but he was difficult to turn and to manage.
This recovery end of the ward, it also functioned as our ICU, our intensive care unit.
There was no other place in the hospital where the lights were always on and where these difficult patients could be handled.
Any times, usually a recovery patient stayed with us for one hour.
That was about it.
But the others, we might have them for days and days.
And so often when we had them that long, that's the way they left.
I mean, they never went in.
They never, they died rather than going to another ward.
And this fellow was one.
He had so many wounds all over.
He was just a multiple fragment wounded patient.
And that's the way they were carried, multiple fragments.
And he had gotten infected.
The wounds there were not only the rips and tears, but these guys were dirty when they were shot.
They were apt to have whatever
was near them was apt to be blown into their wound too.
Or they fell into more yuck and gucky stuff.
Infection was just a real problem.
And he was badly infected.
He was pretty much out of it.
He was running a fever.
He was delirious.
This fennel lasted for about a week.
He lasted days.
I don't know how long it was.
He was skinny.
He was sort of light, auburn-haired.
The sicker he got, the less we did for him in the way of shaving.
His beard was growing.
He was thin-faced.
He seemed to get thinner.
He was faced longer and bags under his eyes, deeper and longer as the days went on.
He didn't have much to say.
When he was talking, he was kind of a country hick.
He was on this skinny bed that was barely as wide as his shoulders.
There's no place for your arms on those striker frames.
They put out arm boards so that, you know, there's a place for the arms.
And then he had IVs going in his arms.
They had to be protected, and they were managed.
I can remember passing him once and thinking,
That's Jesus on the cross.
That's just what it looked like.
And, you know, coming from the Catholic tradition, I'm very familiar with crucifixes, and so many of them all look alike.
It is a very thin, austere-looking man, often a reddish-brownish hair, and a just long, almost, is it Greco?
The artist?
Mm-hmm.
who is so elongated.
And he fit that picture.
He could have been the model for, you know, the crucifix I grew up seeing in my church, my own church.
And later on...
you know, in the past recent years that I have worked through all this, you know, I came to realize, really, that was Jesus on the cross.
That's all of it.
I mean, that's the suffering Christ right here among us.
He could have been Vietnamese.
He could have been the enemy.
He could have been the homeless people we encounter.
Any of the suffering, you know, that is still happening
It didn't hit me that way at the time, it's just it was one of those pictures that I always remembered, and I remembered what I associated it with at the time.
Another patient I remember from that ward was one of the head injured.
And usually those kids, even if they didn't have terrible head injuries, even if they had the type that they were going to recover from, they didn't wake up on the recovery ward.
Their vital signs reached a point where they were safe to move to the ward, post-op ward.
But they didn't wake up.
We didn't have a whole lot of interaction with those patients because the ICU patients were too sick.
And the patients coming into pre-op,
They were pretty much shocked, too.
We just didn't get to visit with them.
This kid woke up very quickly.
We raised the beds of those head injured patients as soon as it was safe to.
And it was while I was raising him up to a more sitting position, he spoke.
He said, hey, you're cute.
And, you know, I laughed at him.
He said, oh, my wife would kill me if she could hear me say that.
And then he said what I heard I don't know how many times was, I haven't seen a round-eyed woman in eight months.
He was wiped out on one side.
It was as if he had had a stroke.
His injury had wiped out function on one side.
And he looked down at himself and he said, I was a steeplejack.
I don't know exactly what he meant by a steeplejack, but he had been used to climbing around.
And he knew, he knew that that was gone.
I don't know.
I never worked on the post-op neuro ward.
I don't know how soon those guys talked or any of the other wards where there were really bad injuries.
I don't know how soon they talked about, if they did talk, what had happened to them and what the ramifications were.
This guy knew.
And there he was in the recovery room recognizing it.
What do you perceive as the differences between nursing in a war zone and nursing at home in 1968?
Well, part of the difference was that motto I taught you, conserve the fighting strength.
The idea in Vietnam was to get a guy, you know, patch him up as best you could and hopefully get him back on the battlefield.
It was not necessarily to save his life.
And that's, you know, that's what we did at home.
That's nursing, medicine, that was the... That's what you always hoped to do.
Maybe there were situations where you would stop short of that, but certainly not the number of times that you're ready to go and be at home.
There was pretty sophisticated surgery done at an EVAC hospital.
It was different from a surgical hospital.
You know, you think of MASH.
Well, that was a surgery hospital.
It was a surgical, a mobile surgical hospital.
And EVAC is where patients go after the surgical hospital.
Now, it was different in Korea and Vietnam in that in Vietnam,
the capacity of the choppers was so much greater than it had been.
That whole medevac system had been refined.
There were many, many choppers.
People were trained.
They carried medics on them.
They didn't have just pilots.
They actually had medics who could, you know,
do procedures while they were in flight, while they were en route to the hospital.
And if the chopper was closer to the back hospital, that's where they went.
Or somebody who had a head wound, for instance, it was, you know, you could go fly just a little bit longer and make it to the 24th.
All the head wounds, all the spinal cord injuries
that happened in that area, in three and four core area, eventually came to our hospital.
And, you know, distances were not terribly great, you know.
It was not an initial for somebody to be taken directly to the 24th and back.
I forgot the question.
There's differences in nursing.
there would still need to be some patients had to have different added
let's say, added procedures done a little bit later.
After having been in Nam, they might have them done in Guam or Tokyo, whereas in the stateside, you know, someone, an accident victim would have everything done.
You know, the wound would be taken care of properly, completely finished, maybe, you know, with one surgery.
Were you aware of any drug abuse when you were in Vietnam?
I knew of some, but really only secondhand.
I mean, I saw none.
Well, no, I won't say I saw none.
It was not the horrible problem that it became, say, a year or two years later.
One of the corpsmen who had worked on the pre-op recovery ward
I'd been getting into trouble with it.
I really wasn't that aware of it on the ward, and I never hung around the enlisted area, living area.
But evidently, he used up all his chances and was rotated out to the field as a medic.
And there he continued his problem.
And I remember him coming in once, coming back into the hospital.
I think he'd come in for treatment.
And he had patches on both arms inside the elbow.
And I said, what happened?
And he said he had taken frag wounds.
And then he showed them to me.
They weren't frag wounds.
Nope, nope, nope, nope, nope.
I knew a nurse who was abusing Ritalin, I think.
She was always up.
She was just always up and smiling and very happy-go-lucky and working hard and this and that.
And she came to me one night, I don't know whether she was working nights or whether she was just up trolling around, and asked for Ritalin.
And, uh-huh, this is why you're always so up.
There are a number of books out, a couple of them, three of them I know of, about women who've been in Vietnam.
And one of them, they each have different stories.
Each chapter is one woman's story, and they all include nurses.
One of them is...
that of a girl who was at the 24th, about 18 months after I was.
And she talks about the drug problems being just very rampant.
I think things did deteriorate.
It got worse.
Morale got worse.
I knew things went on there.
I had another corpsman who smoked pot very frequently.
But it just wasn't very obvious.
A lot of drinking.
A lot of drinking.
And I don't think even then I would have called that a drug problem.
I do now.
People partied hard when they got off work.
And it always included drinking.
